comments.text:
I hate all of this cat vs dog nonsense. I wish more people would look out 
for all animals instead of just one species. And I also wish that people 
wouldn't attack people who like one animal just because they happen to like 
the other. I see it in the comments on every video about pets on YouTube.
I love both cats and dogs. I have both at home. They are two totally 
different animals, and are great in their own ways. I don't think one 
deserves help more than the other.
Both cats and dogs have their unfair disadvantages. And I don't know how 
many times a I hear about a dog(or cat) getting beaten or shot or starved 
and I hear someone say well cats(or dogs) get treated like "THIS"  It 
breaks my heart because they are blinded to the suffering of that animal 
because they only have sight for another. 
Its almost bothers me as much as news of children getting abused and then 
someone saying "well other children get beaten worse". You know what, maybe 
they do, but It does NOT make what happened to that child okay , and does 
nothing to help children suffering from abuse.
 
I'm just saying other dogs, who were more vicious than the one on the video 
have been worked with and rehabilitated, dogs that went directly for the 
throat instead of the leg. I just feel bad that the dog was put down 
because his owner was neglectful. Maybe in the area where they lived they 
don't have the resources to work with him, but its just saddening to me 
that an animal had to die. I don't agree with the original poster, the 
tricycle was at a standstill so it couldn't have drawn the dogs attention. 
And if he were afraid he would be backing away and barking at the tricycle 
and his ears would be back. He bit the boy intentionally. In my opinion it 
was a territorial thing. Because a lot of dog who are locked up in their 
back yards or wherever and are never socialized end up like that. And the 
owners admitted to keeping him locked up and training him as a guard dog.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
+Night b0t Lol, My point wasn't where I lived, I used it as an example to 
refute your statement about only cats being mistreated, I like to back my 
responses instead of just vomiting random bullshit statements with nothing 
to back it up.
 My point, which you continuously keep missing, is that just because you 
think cats have it bad doesn't mean all animals should be looked over.
 I don't care what you give two fucks about and honestly there is not cat 
or dog side when it comes to animal rights. That, you idiot is what I've 
been saying.
 I'm on the side of all animals and I don't think ANY animal should suffer 
cat or dog. But you seem to have tunnel vision for cats and in your narrow 
minded ignorance are missing my point all together.
The reason I am telling you this "shit" is to back up why I disagreed with 
you, that not only cats suffer like you seem to think they do. ALL ANIMALS 
need our help. And when you throw off on a dog being mistreated saying that 
cats are worse off you aren't helping at all. Honestly my entire point went 
way over your head.
 I discussed where I lived because I used it as an example that dogs get 
mistreated too, and to tell you why you were wrong in saying that cats get 
put down all the time and no one does it to dogs. People put their dogs 
down all the time just because they don't want them anymore.
 I can't believe I have to go that far to explain that to you.

Cats being put down because they scratch you soft lol.....
I know people who have SCARS from their cats and still keep them. 

And you know what, horses get put down when they can't race anymore, and 
dogs get put down just for excessive barking.
Not only cats are in danger.

Also, I don't care about you either, I honestly didn't want to sink down to 
this level, but I think you are ignorant, and you have no depth or you 
would have gotten my reasoning the first time I said it instead of going 
off about where I lived.
I also hope that you are still in school because you use too many chat 
abbreviations, have poor grammar, and basically come off sounding like an 
illiterate moron.

Damn..I went there, and am ashamed I went there, but I'm done with you and 
will have no further dialogue with you because you missed my point entirely 
and have nothing intelligent to bring into a debate.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
+Ash K omfg look I dont know whos side you are on but im on the cats side 
this time so I dont need you to tell me all this shit or were you used to 
live, I dont give 2 fucks about you god I tried to say it nicely earlier 
but you tell me all this bullshit i dont need to fucking know!!!! ( 
language )
comments.author: Night b0t

comments.text:
+Night b0t People DO defend cats. There just aren't enough of them. And I 
know of cat people who hate dogs that will swerve on the road to hit dogs 
when they are driving. So it goes both ways. And cats CAN hurt you when 
they bite. My grandma had to get stitches after her cat attacked her. And 
there are certain breeds of dog that no one will defend and just assume 
they are bad and kill them for what they are. A woman's dog was shot 11 
times by police just because it was a pitbull, they were even caught 
premeditating it before they arrived to the house. Her father was watching 
the dog and it got loose and someone called the police and reported it. The 
dog was a still a pup and wasn't showing any aggression at all and was 
running away from the police when it was shot. How many cats get shot by 
the police for no reason? Another policeman shot a dog in someones backyard 
when he went to check for a suspect and went to the wrong house. Yeah cats 
get treated like shit, but so do dogs. There should be more and stricter 
laws protecting animals but there aren't and it doesn't help when people 
say "oh well cats are treated like this" when a dog is treated poorly. It 
the same when someone reports a cat being beaten and someone says "well 
dogs get beat all the time." no matter what is done to a cat or what is 
done to a dog it is still WRONG when ONE of them is mistreated. And 
downplaying it by saying that one or the other gets worse treatment, does 
nothing to help out all animals in general.

Do you know that in the south where I used to be from, there are packs of 
wild dogs where people just dump them on the side of the road when they no 
longer want them, and cars swerve to hit them? And in the south most don't 
really believe in taking dogs OR cats (but mostly dogs) to shelters and 
just take them out and shoot them when they dont want them anymore because 
"they're just dogs" I used to live in KY and although its gotten better, it 
is still a problem.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
+Ash K omfg im saying that other people dont really defend cats put down 
just because they scratch you soft. Im not saying you. Im not saying people 
who love cats. Im saying that people who love dogs and hate cats they 
normally say oh I kill every cat I see. Like come on. I think everyone 
deserves a chance even that dog. Im just saying bearly people care about 
poor little cats and they dont bite you that hard they are not tiger -_-
comments.author: Night b0t

comments.text: IT DOESN'T MATTER ANYMORE THIS IS GETTING OLD
comments.author: Lynne Griffen

comments.text:
I've lived with both cats and dogs my whole life. Love them both. Even 
experts who have reviewed the video have pointed out that the dogs body 
language was one of aggression/predatory, not fear. And the dog most 
certainly did harm. Did you see the boys leg, the extent of the injury. If 
Tara had not intervened I could have been a tragically worse mauling. 
Stating that the dog acted aggressively is not a slight on the dog or dogs 
in general. Like with cats, or kids even, a lot of undesirable behaviour 
comes down to training, lack of it, or inconsistent. First, that dog should 
not have been available to run loose, unattended on the streets. They are 
predator animals after all.

My own dog, as sweat and gentle as she was, and she was, I still would 
never have run lease free unless in a designated leash free area (which 
would include our backyard). And she would still be supervised in some way.
comments.author: Benevolent Witness

comments.text:
+Night b0t So just because according to you no one cares about cats being 
put down, it's okay to kill other species of animals? Cats bite people all 
the time and they still keep them as pets and most of them say, "oh cat's 
are just temperamental". If I had a quarter for every time I heard that 
one. My grandmas cat put her into the hospital, and she still kept it. She 
was diabetic and the bites and scratches messed her up bad.

But usually when a dog bites (other than small dogs) it is immediately 
gone. I guess it has to do with smaller animals not causing as much damage. 
My in-law's German Shepard was put down after it bit his hand, but my 
in-law decided that beating the shit out of his dog was a proper form of 
dog training. The poor dog would get scared and piss himself when he was 
yelled at. He did NOT deserve to be put down, no matter how many cats you 
think were wrongfully euthanized.  Every animal deserves the chance to live.

 There are organizations out there that work on saving cats from "death 
row" I know this because I adopted a cat through one of those 
organizations, she was 20 years old and was going to be put down because of 
her age and aggression toward strangers. Her owner was an elderly woman who 
just passed away. I agree that there is an epidemic of feral cats, no one 
spays or neuters them and lets them run wild and become over populated, and 
some animal shelters will put them down regardless of their temperament 
because they are overrun and most people go there to adopt puppies. There 
should be more organizations for cats, especially for feral cats.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
I watched the video from Good Morning America and, according to GMA, the 
dog was a guard dog.  If it was a guard dog, it should have never been 
allowed outside of the fence.  Guard dogs are trained to protect their 
territory which could cause them to attack people they do not know.  While 
I don't necessarily agree with putting the dog down, common law demands 
that biting dogs are to be put down.  This law goes back to the time of 
William the Conqueror.  I sympathize with those who don't like the idea of 
killing the dog, but I've witnessed guard dogs attack and kill cats that 
strayed into the property they were "guarding".  I didn't like it.  But, 
the cat WAS in their territory.  This child on the other hand was in his 
yard and the dog sought him out.  That kind of dog cannot ever be trusted 
again in my opinion because he broke the trust that humans place in dogs.  
I fully expect to be attacked for my views but I just don't care.
comments.author: Glenn Sellers

comments.text:

top_comment.text:
That's what I'm sayin, man... wonderfully brave cat, but the dog shouldn't 
just be killed off for this... What was it in that dog's background that 
taught him that attacking a child like that was okay...?? What did the 
dog's owners teach him--what did they *not* teach him? ... Isn't there some 
kind of training that this dog could go through or something...??﻿
top_comment.author: Fyrsiel

comments.text:
Animals are like people, I agree, but unfortunately what holds an animal 
back is pure lack of communication. If this dog understood that he would be 
put to death if he ever attacked another human being, I'd wager that the 
dog probably wouldn't have done so in order to save his own skin (just like 
most any human being might). But since the dog doesn't know, then as far as 
the dog is concerned, there are no rules. So how do we combat that 
situation??  The frustration comes from the fact that a guy could 
mercilessly beat another guy but he'll only be put in jail. He won't 
automatically be thrown into Death Row, and while he's in jail, an attempt 
will be made to "rehabilitate" him in an ideal world... truth be told, 
"rehabilitation" doesn't really happen most of the time, but the point is, 
for our own people, even if a guy is mercilessly violent, the mindset is 
that we should try to "fix" him, even spend a couple of years doing so, not 
kill him off immediately. But the decision to execute animals comes far 
more easily. It's the nearly complete lack of effort to try to fix the 
situation first that's unsettling.
comments.author: Fyrsiel

comments.text:

was too dangerous. To many environmentalists in this group. Sometimes it is

Animals are very much like people. Sometimes everyone tries to figure out

environmental cause. Sometimes the individual is just mentally unstable.

You can't really teach a cat to do anything it doesn't want to do.  The 
best you can do is give it a lot of love and it will love you back.  The 
limits of that love is entirely up to the cat, plain and simple.  I can say 
that most cats will attempt to defend the one(s) they love.  I had two cats 
once that protected me from a drunk of a woman who I allowed to stay at my 
place until she found another place.  She would get drunk and verbally 
attack me.  My cats, who just happened to be kittens of her cat, didn't 
like it and would growl and hiss at her.  One even scratched her when she 
attempted to pet it after she went into one of her tirades against me.

top_comment.text:
My cat is my baby girl. I would walk through fire for her, I would swim 
through frozen rivers just to see her happy and safe. I feel the same about 
my dorkie. They are my children, my companions, my friends. Neither would 
ever bite, anyone, but should there ever be a bite, I would fight tooth and 
fucking nail to see them either re-homed, or I would go through every 
obedience training thing I could find to fix what ever it was that I did to 
fuck my pets up in the first place. It sickens me that this dog, who was 
obviously not cared for properly in the first place, (running loose, no 
collar, allowed to establish a territory outside his own yard, territorial 
about the neighbors yard)  is going to pay the price with his life because 
no one ever taught him to behave himself. We treat HUMAN murderers better 
than we do neglected and mistreated dogs, and dogs are basically going on 
dead instinct until we teach them different. I just don't understand why 
the owners didn't fight for him. Were they that shitty that they didn't 
even try to save him? Before or after?﻿

+ScarletLetter86
Totally agree.
comments.author: jewelmarkess

comments.text: Exactly my thoughts, especially because this is a high-profile case.
comments.author: Pilar Dueñas

comments.text:
You know I think you made some really great points. I don't think these 
owners should be allowed to have another dog if they couldn't even control 
a puppy. As for the dog repeatedly biting, it sounds like it was scared and 
in a place where people didn't know how to handle the aggression. I 
understand why the dog was put down and no I would not have given it back 
to the previous owners for rehabilitation and in a perfect would he would 
have been taken to a place where dogs are retaught and become useful 
members of society, but you are correct, this isn't a perfect world and 
there ARE thousands of non aggressive dogs that are put down every week 
simply because irresponsible people breed with out thinking, or owners 
don't want the responsibility. (not that its always so cut and dry, but 
more than anything its those two reasons) Truth is, its done and there is 
not a damn thing I can do about it. I just think that dog ownership should 
be far more regulated.

Also cats can and do kill, but most of the time its an accident. They have 
been known to suffocate infants by either sleeping on them, or licking 
their mouths so they can't breathe. But more likely, cats can give disease 
through bites and scratches that left untreated can become life threatening.

I guess I'm more angry at the owners because they just failed that dog one 
time after another. Don't get a dog if you can't handle it.
comments.author: ScarletLetter86

comments.text:
+ScarletLetter86
I am a bit on a fence here. I feel sorry for a dog especially as it's still 
a puppy - 7-8 months old. I have cats, and I'd not dream of putting them to 
sleep if they turn aggressive, but cats are different from dogs: they can't 
kill you, they don't hunt people, and they usually have a reason for their 
aggression one can deal with. I don't know much about dog behavior though. 
It's impossible to imagine a cat going after a child outside, and indoors 
they can be easily supervised. My cousin has an aggressive biter cat, and 
she retrained him.

I did however read more about this particular case. Interestingly, the 
mother of the child didn't want to kill the dog and hoped it could be 
retrained. Incidentally, what we don't see on the video is that the reason 
the mother went away is that the dog came around the car and wanted to 
attack again. The mother chased it away, and it bit the mother. In the 
shelter where it was for observation for two weeks, it bit everyone there. 
Could it have been retrained - maybe, but if the owner doesn't fight for 
the dog, do you think anybody would? Can the dog be trusted not to attack 
again? I suppose it could have been muzzled outside, but at any rate, the 
owner didn't want to fight. It's obvious that the owner should have trained 
the dog and should've kept the dog in the yard. None of these things 
happened. Now, would anybody trust this particular owner? What if next time 
the dog kills someone? At any rate, with so many sweet friendly animals 
killed in shelters, would anybody else take this dog? Keep in mind, that 
knowingly keeping an aggressive dog is a huge liability risk if the dog 
bites someone. If the dog seriously injures and kills someone the owner can 
end up in jail. Of course, a responsible owner could've muzzled the dog 
outside, and kept it leashed inside.

These are some of the things to consider.
comments.author: jewelmarkess

comments.text:
+WILTALK
While I respect that you are allowed your personal opinions, I will argue 
against one point you made. Dogs have less intelligence than a four year 
old, and the bite of a killer, thus they are very much akin to a person 
with mental retardation. I used to work with mentally deficient individuals 
and they were capable of hurting me with out blinking an eye and on several 
occasions I walked away with massive bruises, lacerations, and various 
other personal injuries. Now are you telling me that a being that has less 
reasoning capability than a moderately mentally retarded person is anything 
like a mass murderer? And by your logic should we be putting those with 
mental disabilities to death before we allow them a chance to learn and 
grow? One particular individual I worked with was born with fetal alchohol 
syndrome and had very bad reasoning skills and would spend her time 
"hunting out" the weak staff and she would attack them mercilessly. I was 
placed in the house and when I stood up to her she attacked me and on more 
than one occasion. That was two years ago. When I left the company I was 
working for we had her calm, she was happy, on a schedule and productive in 
her work place. Had we simply thrown her in a padded cell and left her to 
rot she wouldn't be the person she is today. She would have lost her 
apartment, and lost her dear roommate and friend. She would have wilted. No 
its not always nurture over nature but I think to throw away a life simply 
because a dog isn't an easy fix is cruel and unusual punishment.
comments.author: ScarletLetter86

comments.text:
And would you hide and fight for a relative that was a mass murderer? There 
are a lot of dogs under similar conditions that don't end up attacking 
children. Just like two different people will not always make the same 
choices in similar circumstances. You have been indoctrinated into the 
environmentalist belief that is responsible for the decline of social 
responsibility and morality in our present society. We are not ( and 
animals aren't either but to a lesser degree) simple a product of our 
environment. Sometimes it is nothing that was done to it, but simple what 
something was to begin with. Vick killed some of his dogs because he 
couldn't get them to be vicious and fight. Some dogs are vicious to begin 
with and you couldn't get them to be otherwise. All you can do is isolate 
them and that is not always possible.
comments.author: WILTALK

comments.text:
It is sad. Of course its the responsibility of the owners. The human owners 
of the dog should've a) trained him not to attack humans b) kept him in 
their yard.
comments.author: jewelmarkess

top_comment.text:
I knew this would happen. i clicked this video for cats, now billions of 
comments saying "Oh i hope they dont kill the dog!" can somebody tell me 
why people prefer dogs over cats? And they dont even care about the kid 
they just want to help the dog, which would have been a murderer if the cat 
didnt come in.﻿
top_comment.author: Aqua Kitty

comments.text:
Also, cats can be aggressive too, to the point where people want to put 
them down. My grandma was told over and over to put her cat down. It was 
her grandsons cat who died at aged 17. My grandma raised him (grandson). It 
started biting and scratching her and it put her in the hospital because of 
her diabetes. She never gave up on that cat. Eventually my aunt from out of 
state came and took it when my grandma had to be put in the home because 
her dementia got so bad. The cat was never the same after my cousin passed 
away but my grandma didn't give up on it and my aunt could have had it put 
down but didn't and took it home with her.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
+Alicia Spencer I agree. To me it has nothing to do with liking cats/dogs 
better. It has everything to do with the fact that I think the dog 
shouldn't have to pay for its owners negligence. The dog wasn't very old, 
and was obviously not socialized correctly, they even said they got it as a 
guard dog. Every pet has the right to life. The dog should go to someone 
who can handle that kind of dog. I think people who adopt dogs who are on 
death row at shelter are among the most amazing people in the world because 
they go into it knowing that that animal is going to need work. I'm not 
worried about the other dogs there that "place" it is going to take because 
people will most likely take the dog that isn't going to be a lot of 
trouble. It takes a RARE person to want to work with a troubled dog. My 
aunts dog used to be aggressive. She was beaten by her owners so badly she 
had broken teeth. A loving home and owners willing to work with her did 
wonders. She eventually started playing with the kids, and acting like a 
nanny dog to the babies, she turned into big lap dog. She lived to be 20 
years old and sadly passed away 2 days ago. I am proud of my aunt for not 
giving up on that dog and giving it a chance that most people wouldn't be 
willing to give her. 

I do feel bad for the kid, but just because I don't think the dog should be 
killed doesn't mean I think its okay that he bit him.
comments.author: Ash K

comments.text:
+WILTALK
THAT IS NOT WHAT I MEANT. All dogs should have homes, it's just this 
comment section is about this dog. I am all for shelters, but breeders and 
puppy mills are horrid.
comments.author: Alicia Spencer

comments.text:
+Alicia Spencer What about all the really good dogs that are left with out 
homes every day and get put down. What about them. Most of you are so 
worried about a vicious dog that you forget that that dog would be taking 
the place of a dog who did nothing wrong. Give you a clue -- there are not 
enough resources and homes to go around. So lets put our resources into 
rehabilitating the bad boys and throw those that are good under the bus. 
When we deal with limited resources hard choices have to be made. Most of 
you are so focused on helping the really screwed up that you forget you 
might be doing at the expense of those that are not.
comments.author: WILTALK

comments.text:
I love all animals, so I don't want anyone to put down that dog. Proper 
training and a better owner could work out.
comments.author: Alicia Spencer

top_comment.text:
Anyone ever think that the kid could have terrorized the dog prior to in 
the past and the dog saw the kid as a threat? Food for thought...﻿
top_comment.author: Tammy Thomas

comments.text:
The kid is 4 years old, if he was 12 then maybe, but a 4 year old kid 
wouldn't be 'terrorizing" a dog that size.  Either way the kid was in his 
driveway and the dog sought him out and attacked without any provocation, 
the kid never saw it coming.  I LOVE dogs, but I don't think dogs grasp the 
concept of revenge sneak attacks.
comments.author: RatedRKJerichO

comments.text:
Yes, rose monti -- [or at least] the child could have provoked the dog -- 
it happens every day in my neighborhood [fools].  Not only did the dog need 
human supervision [i.e. stay in its own yard or on a leash w/clued-in 
owners] AND the child not playing among vehicles in a driveway or near a 
street, but in his own yard, and supervised as well. I do not blame either 
animal, & the child did not deserve any injuries but was still in harms' 
way where he was. I blame clueless human "adults" -- 99.99999% of the time.
comments.author: SafePet Haven

top_comment.text:
Cat's are full of the depth of emotional love for their humans. They may 
not show it all the time...but my two kittehs know when I'm sad or sick and 
stick to me like glue. :) cat's rule. I too am not happy with them killing 
the dog.﻿
top_comment.author: Ann4U2000

comments.text:
It sure is right what you just said and right to stand up for the dog I'm 
not really a dog person but I mean seriously?! As much as those dog licks 
grossed me out killing the dog is not an answer, the right one is taking 
the dog to a kind trainer that would be nice.
comments.author: cute nightfury

comments.text: My head understands your points. My heart is another matter all together.
comments.author: Ann4U2000

comments.text:
I am not happy killing anything either, but there are so many dogs that get 
put down every year and never even have their first chance.  Why waste a 
lot of time and effort on a dog that has serious issues and seems to see 
small children as prey. Put the effort into making sure that those 
thousands of good dogs are adopted and placed into homes. There eventually 
comes a time when you must triage and make optimum use of limited 
resources.
comments.author: WILTALK

top_comment.text:
I really think people are missing the bigger picture on this dog who bit 
the toddler's leg while the child was riding a bicycle. My sweet dog, whose 
name is JACKSON, gets wildly confused by people on bikes. When I walk him 
past kids on skateboards, bikes (and even our maintenance dudes riding the 
golf carts), he barks and goes a little bonkers. It's not about aggression 
towards people, but rather, aggression towards those strange, noisy, 
spinning things. When I saw that now famous cat video, I felt really bad 
for the dog, who clearly saw the spinning wheels underneath the car, got 
fixated on it, and then went in for the 'kill'. The child's leg just 
happened to be in between.  I teach the kids here in my large complex that 
my dog will bark if they zip past us on bikes or skateboards, so please get 
off the bikes/skateboards, for just a moment to let us pass.  They really 
do 'get it' so I'm not really understanding why the rest of the world 
won't.﻿
top_comment.author: TheStarProphet1

comments.text: Oh pulllease! You are absolutely clueless!
comments.author: TheStarProphet1

comments.text:
Here let me help you; what do you do when you walk past rolling whees? You 
tense up, you don't really correct him. Maybe you go "No, Jackson, stop it" 
in a not so convincing voice. Dogs don't listen to fear and insecurity. 
They don't follow unstable leaders. That's why he does whatever he wants. 
You need to read the signs. They're not humans! They're dogs, with 
instincts. The dog in that video was first stalking the kid, then he was 
tugging the kid back and forth in his mouth, like dogs do when they kill 
their prey. Not the bike. No one has taught him otherwise, just like you 
haven't diciplined your dog. It's always the owners. That's why this dog 
got killed. For something a human started. I can see you're taking it 
personally since you immediately started talking about your dog, so let me 
just say; take better care of your dog please. Stop toning it down saying 
"he goes a little bonkers" and do something about it!
comments.author: CodenameTurtle

captions.text: [THEME MUSIC]

And a hush falls over
the internet world.
A hush.
Why?
Because a cat did something.
Not jumped in a box.
Not played the keyboards.
No, no.

A cat did something that made
everybody go what the what?
Did you see what the cat did?

Let's talk about what
the cat did folks.
We are catafying the world.
Let's go.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

If you have been
hanging out under a rock

for the past couple of days let
me tell you who Tara cat is.

Outside of Bakersfield,
California,

security cameras at
this family's home

caught one of the
most incredible things

you're ever going
to see on video.

Which is their young
son, four years old,

playing on a tricycle
in the street.

Then another camera catches this
dog coming from the neighbors
and hunting this kid.
He sees the kid.

He goes around the
car and kabang.
Attacks that kid.
Very hard to watch.

But just as it begins
Tara the cat, who

belongs with this child and with
his family, phew, she's in man.
She's in.

She just absolute
terrorizes the dog.
Chases the dog off.
Here's where it gets amazing.

Because as she chases him
around the car, peels off,
goes back to the kid.
What the what was that?
Yes, that was a cat.

And that is why everybody
is so freaked out.

Not because a dog
rescued a child.

It's because a cat
rescued a child.

As a culture we
have just recognize

that a cat can be
a hero to a child.
It Is irrefutable.
It is right there.

You're asking me is
the cat experiencing

some kind of protective
mechanism over that child

or is the cat just
hunting the dog?
Folks.

If you've seen it there's
no mistaking what that is.
Right?

That is a cat who's like,
do not touch my child.

Think about all the other
little pieces of this puzzle.

Was she a pure bred
cat who was bought

from breeder or
something like that?
Or a pet store?
No.

She was a stray who followed
Erica, the woman, home one day
from a walk and she kept her.

Even though Erica was allergic
to cats she still kept Tara.

That move to allow that
cat to be with that child

at such an early age
saved that child.

That child's life
is saved from a cat

who feels that fierce
sense of protection.

That maternal, even fraternal,
sense of protection.

Because in part, that bond was
formed at such an early age.
And then she chases that dog.

And then when the
dog is gone she

peels off, goes back,
and says, are you OK?
That is just heartwarming stuff.

Now, I'm telling you man,
if you're already here
with Team Cat Mojo we know.

We know the depth
of cat emotions.

We know that cats feel as
much as any other animal.

We know that cats feel
as much as humans do.

Now, for me and for all
the people out there

who comprise Team Cat Mojo,
we're pretty siked folks,
we're pretty siked.
You know Why?
This is our Lassie moment.

This is that moment in
time where all of a sudden

a cat is the one that we're
like, Timmy's caught in a well
well well.
Lassie, Lassie, Lassie.
Right?
And then Lassie comes.
In this case, Tara.
And the cat comes in.
It's our Lassie moment.

And we should freakin
stand up and applaud.

And welcome in all the new
folks to Team Cat Mojo.
Man, now you know.

Now you get a
glimpse of what cats
can offer you in your life.

Not just because they're
going to guard your property

and protect your
children, but now

you see the depth
of that emotion.

And you think to
yourself, man, I really

thought cats didn't
feel that way.

They just act so aloff, so
independent, so apart from us.
Now you know.
Now you know.

I have to say this because
amidst all of the jubilation

around what Tara
did there's the dog.

And I don't even
know the dog's name.
That's the sad part.

We don't even know
this dog's name.

The dog, yes, he
attacked Jeremy.
Yes he did.
And then he was scared away.

He is then promptly
given up by his people.

He is now under, quote,
"voluntary observation".

Which is to say he's under a
ten day bite quarantine placed

on him by the
Bakersfield Police.

At which point, after 10
days he will be killed.

That people, does not
make any sense at all.

It is not right
to kill this dog.

I don't care what
you think about him.

Don't forget he is a product
of where he was raised.

That's all I got
to say about that.
So, yay to Tara.

Yay to all people who see
cats in a brand new way.

Yay to the people who already
knew cats were all that.
And yay to our Lassie moment.

Until the next time
we speak folks.

Don't forget you can
find me in all these fun
places right around here.

Also, watch all these
videos around me here.

We have plenty of good stuff,
good information for you
to take a look at.

Also, don't forget, if
you hashtag TeamCatMojo
I will see it.
I will respond to it.
Most of the time anyhow.
But hey I'm looking.

Also, don't forget folks,
I want to see your cats
watching "My Cat From Hell".

And your dogs watching
"My Cat From Hell".
It's this weird phenomenon.
I'd like to see you do it.

So just #CatsWatchingMCFH
or #DogsWatchingMCFH.

I want to gather up
all those pictures

and I want to put them together
and have some fun with it.

All right folks,
until next time.

All like, all love,
all mojo to you.
[KISS] Love you.

title: Is Hero Cat The New Lassie?
